<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0"
         xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
         xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0
         http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
    <modelVersion>4.0.0</modelVersion>

    <groupId>io.quarkus</groupId>
    <artifactId>maven-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>999-SNAPSHOT</version>
    <packaging>maven-plugin</packaging>

    <properties>
        <maven.compiler.source>21</maven.compiler.source>
        <maven.compiler.target>21</maven.compiler.target>
        <project.build.sourceEncoding>UTF-8</project.build.sourceEncoding>
        <maven.version>3.8.8</maven.version>
    </properties>

    <dependencies>
        <!-- Maven Plugin API -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-plugin-api</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
        </dependency>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugin-tools</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-plugin-annotations</artifactId>
            <version>3.9.0</version>
            <scope>provided</scope>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- Maven Core for MavenSession -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-core</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- Maven Project -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-model</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- JSON output -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.google.code.gson</groupId>
            <artifactId>gson</artifactId>
            <version>2.10.1</version>
        </dependency>
        
        <!-- Test Dependencies -->
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugin-testing</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-plugin-testing-harness</artifactId>
            <version>3.3.0</version>
            <scope>test</scope>
        </dependency>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>org.apache.maven</groupId>
            <artifactId>maven-compat</artifactId>
            <version>${maven.version}</version>
            <scope>test</scope>
        </dependency>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>junit</groupId>
            <artifactId>junit</artifactId>
            <version>4.13.2</version>
            <scope>test</scope>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>

    <build>
        <plugins>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.11.0</version>
                <configuration>
                    <source>21</source>
                    <target>21</target>
                </configuration>
            </plugin>
            <plugin>
                <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
                <artifactId>maven-plugin-plugin</artifactId>
                <version>3.9.0</version>
                <configuration>
                    <goalPrefix>nx</goalPrefix>
                </configuration>
                <executions>
                    <execution>
                        <id>default-descriptor</id>
                        <goals>
                            <goal>descriptor</goal>
                        </goals>
                    </execution>
                </executions>
            </plugin>
        </plugins>
    </build>
</project>

input.content:
# Maven Plugin Install Functionality Analysis

## Overview
This document analyzes the current Maven plugin implementation to understand how `nx install` works and identify the key files and functionality.

## Key Maven Plugin Files

### 1. Maven Plugin Structure
```
maven-plugin/
 pom.xml                    # Maven plugin configuration
 src/main/java/
    NxAnalyzerMojo.java    # Main plugin entry point
    TargetGenerationService.java # Target generation logic
    TargetDependencyService.java # Dependency calculation
    TargetGroupService.java      # Target grouping
    MavenUtils.java              # Maven utilities
    model/                       # Data models
 target/                    # Compiled plugin
```

### 2. TypeScript Integration
- `maven-plugin.ts` - Nx plugin integration that delegates to Java
- `nx.json` - Nx configuration with Maven plugin registration

## Current Install Implementation

### How `nx install` Currently Works

1. **Phase Target Generation**: The `install` phase is automatically created as a no-op target
2. **Goal Target Dependencies**: The `install` phase depends on:
   - `verify` - Previous Maven lifecycle phase
   - `maven-install:install` - Actual Maven install plugin goal
   - `^install` - Install targets from dependent projects

3. **Maven Install Plugin Target**: 
   - Executor: `nx:run-commands`
   - Command: `mvn org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-install-plugin:install`
   - Dependencies: `verify`, `^install`

### Key Code Locations

#### 1. NxAnalyzerMojo.java (Lines 194-196)
```java
String[] phases = {
    "clean", "validate", "compile", "test", "package", 
    "verify", "install", "deploy", "site"
};
```
The `install` phase is included in the standard Maven lifecycle phases.

#### 2. TargetGenerationService.java (Lines 308-343)
```java
private Set<String> getApplicablePhases(MavenProject project) {
    // Dynamically discovers phases with bound goals
    // Falls back to minimal essential phases including "install"
}
```

#### 3. TargetGroupService.java (Line 91)
```java
descriptions.put("install", "Install package to local repository");
```

#### 4. Maven Plugin Detection
The plugin automatically detects `maven-install-plugin` and creates corresponding targets.

## Maven Lifecycle Integration

### Current Flow
1. **Phase Discovery**: Uses Maven's `LifecycleExecutor` to find applicable phases
2. **Goal Binding**: Analyzes which goals are bound to each phase
3. **Target Creation**: Creates both phase targets and goal targets
4. **Dependency Calculation**: Uses `TargetDependencyService` to calculate inter-project dependencies

### Install Phase Behavior
- **Type**: Maven lifecycle phase
- **Purpose**: Install artifacts to local repository (~/.m2/repository)
- **Dependencies**: Automatically calculated based on Maven lifecycle
- **Implementation**: Delegates to `maven-install-plugin:install`

## How Dependencies Work

### Project Dependencies
- Calculated using Maven's reactor project dependencies
- Cross-project dependencies use `^install` syntax
- Ensures correct build order across multi-module projects

### Phase Dependencies
- Follows Maven lifecycle order (compile  test  package  verify  install)
- Enforced through `dependsOn` relationships in Nx targets

## Usage Patterns

### Running Install
```bash
nx install <project-name>    # Install single project
nx run-many --target=install # Install all projects
```

### What Happens
1. Nx resolves dependencies (`verify`, dependent projects)
2. Runs Maven install plugin for each project
3. Artifacts are installed to local Maven repository
4. Build cache is updated

## Key Insights

1. **Dual System**: Install works through both Nx orchestration and Maven execution
2. **Automatic Discovery**: No manual configuration needed - plugins auto-discovered
3. **Dependency-Aware**: Respects both Maven lifecycle and project dependencies
4. **Caching**: Nx provides caching layer over Maven operations

## Files That Handle Install Functionality

### Core Implementation
- `NxAnalyzerMojo.java` - Orchestrates analysis and phase discovery
- `TargetGenerationService.java` - Creates install phase and goal targets
- `TargetDependencyService.java` - Calculates install dependencies
- `maven-plugin.ts` - Provides Nx integration layer

### Configuration
- `nx.json` - Registers Maven plugin with Nx
- Individual `pom.xml` files - Define Maven install plugin bindings

### Generated Targets
- `install` - Maven lifecycle phase (no-op orchestrator)
- `maven-install:install` - Actual Maven install plugin execution

2. Runs Maven install plugin for each project
3. Artifacts are installed to local Maven repository
4. Build cache is updated

## Key Insights

1. **Dual System**: Install works through both Nx orchestration and Maven execution
2. **Automatic Discovery**: No manual configuration needed - plugins auto-discovered
3. **Dependency-Aware**: Respects both Maven lifecycle and project dependencies
4. **Caching**: Nx provides caching layer over Maven operations

## Files That Handle Install Functionality

### Core Implementation
- `NxAnalyzerMojo.java` - Orchestrates analysis and phase discovery
- `TargetGenerationService.java` - Creates install phase and goal targets
- `TargetDependencyService.java` - Calculates install dependencies
- `maven-plugin.ts` - Provides Nx integration layer

### Configuration
- `nx.json` - Registers Maven plugin with Nx
- Individual `pom.xml` files - Define Maven install plugin bindings

### Generated Targets
- `install` - Maven lifecycle phase (no-op orchestrator)
- `maven-install:install` - Actual Maven install plugin execution

Now I'll provide a comprehensive summary of the Maven plugin implementation and how nx install works:

## Maven Plugin Implementation Analysis

Based on my exploration of the codebase, here's how the Maven plugin integration and `nx install` functionality currently works:

### Key Implementation Files

#### 1. **Java Maven Plugin** (`/home/jason/projects/triage/java/quarkus/maven-plugin/`)
- **`NxAnalyzerMojo.java`** - Main Maven plugin entry point that orchestrates analysis
- **`TargetGenerationService.java`** - Generates Nx targets from Maven project configuration
- **`TargetDependencyService.java`** - Calculates dependencies between Maven goals and phases
- **`TargetGroupService.java`** - Groups related targets together
- **`MavenUtils.java`** - Utility functions for Maven operations
- **`pom.xml`** - Maven plugin configuration with goal prefix `nx`

#### 2. **TypeScript Integration** (`/home/jason/projects/triage/java/quarkus/`)
- **`maven-plugin.ts`** - Nx plugin that delegates to the Java analyzer
- **`nx.json`** - Nx workspace configuration registering the Maven plugin

### How `nx install` Currently Works

The install functionality operates through a **dual-layer system**:

1. **Maven Lifecycle Phase**: An `install` phase target is automatically created as a no-op orchestrator
2. **Maven Plugin Goal**: A `maven-install:install` target executes the actual Maven install plugin

#### Target Structure Example:
```json
{
  "install": {
    "executor": "nx:noop",
    "dependsOn": ["verify", "maven-install:install", "^install"]
  },
  "maven-install:install": {
    "executor": "nx:run-commands", 
    "options": {
      "command": "mvn org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-install-plugin:install",
      "cwd": "core/runtime"
    },
    "dependsOn": ["verify", "^install"]
  }
}
```

### Maven Lifecycle Integration

The plugin leverages Maven's official APIs to understand the workspace:

1. **Phase Discovery**: Uses `LifecycleExecutor` to dynamically discover applicable Maven phases
2. **Goal Binding**: Analyzes which plugin goals are bound to each lifecycle phase
3. **Dependency Calculation**: Uses Maven's reactor to understand inter-project dependencies
4. **Target Generation**: Creates both phase targets (orchestrators) and goal targets (executors)

### Key Features

- **Automatic Discovery**: No manual configuration needed - plugin goals are auto-discovered from `pom.xml` files
- **Dependency-Aware**: Respects both Maven lifecycle order and cross-project dependencies
- **Caching**: Nx provides intelligent caching over Maven operations
- **Multi-Module Support**: Handles complex dependency graphs in large Maven projects like Quarkus

### Current Install Command Usage

```bash
nx install <project-name>        # Install specific project to local repo
nx run-many --target=install     # Install all projects 
nx install --all                 # Install entire workspace
```

The implementation follows Maven's standard behavior - installing built artifacts to the local Maven repository (`~/.m2/repository`) while providing Nx's orchestration, caching, and dependency management benefits.

This approach maintains full compatibility with Maven while adding Nx's powerful features for monorepo management and build optimization.

content.text: Now let me look at how Maven handles goal orchestration vs how Nx currently does it:

input.content:
# Maven vs Nx Goal Orchestration Analysis

## Key Differences: `mvn install` vs `nx install`

### Maven's `mvn install` Behavior
- **Single Command**: Executes entire lifecycle from `validate`  `install`
- **Goal Orchestration**: Maven automatically runs all bound goals in correct order:
  1. `validate` phase goals
  2. `initialize` phase goals  
  3. `generate-sources` phase goals
  4. `process-sources` phase goals
  5. `generate-resources` phase goals
  6. `process-resources` phase goals
  7. `compile` phase goals
  8. `process-classes` phase goals
  9. `generate-test-sources` phase goals
  10. `process-test-sources` phase goals
  11. `generate-test-resources` phase goals
  12. `process-test-resources` phase goals
  13. `test-compile` phase goals
  14. `process-test-classes` phase goals
  15. `test` phase goals
  16. `prepare-package` phase goals
  17. `package` phase goals
  18. `pre-integration-test` phase goals
  19. `integration-test` phase goals
  20. `post-integration-test` phase goals
  21. `verify` phase goals
  22. `install` phase goals (maven-install-plugin:install)

### Nx's Current `nx install` Behavior
- **Two-Layer System**:
  - `install` target: noop orchestrator with dependencies
  - `maven-install:install` target: actual Maven install plugin execution
- **Limited Orchestration**: Only orchestrates up to `verify` phase, then jumps to install goal
- **Missing Phases**: Doesn't execute all intermediate phases that Maven would run

## Current Gap Analysis

### What's Missing in Nx
1. **Incomplete Lifecycle**: Nx doesn't run all Maven phases before install
2. **Goal Skipping**: Some bound goals in intermediate phases might be skipped
3. **Plugin Goal Discovery**: Not all plugin goals are discovered and orchestrated

### Current Target Structure
```json
{
  "install": {
    "executor": "nx:noop",
    "dependsOn": ["verify", "maven-install:install", "^install"]
  },
  "maven-install:install": {
    "executor": "nx:run-commands",
    "command": "mvn org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-install-plugin:install",
    "dependsOn": ["verify", "^install"]
  }
}
```

## Solution Requirements

To make `nx install` work exactly like `mvn install`, Nx needs to:

1. **Dynamic Phase Discovery**: Use `LifecycleExecutor.calculateExecutionPlan()` to get complete execution plan
2. **Goal Orchestration**: Create targets for all bound goals in execution order
3. **Phase Targets**: Maintain phase-level targets as orchestrators
4. **Dependency Chain**: Ensure proper dependency chain from validate  install

## Implementation Strategy

The `TargetGenerationService` already has the foundation with:
- `getApplicablePhases()` - discovers bound phases dynamically  
- `hasGoalsBoundToPhase()` - checks if phase has goals
- `LifecycleExecutor` integration - can calculate full execution plans

Need to enhance to:
1. Generate targets for ALL phases in lifecycle order
2. Create proper dependency chains between phases
3. Ensure all bound goals are orchestrated correctly

- **Two-Layer System**:
  - `install` target: noop orchestrator with dependencies
  - `maven-install:install` target: actual Maven install plugin execution
- **Limited Orchestration**: Only orchestrates up to `verify` phase, then jumps to install goal
- **Missing Phases**: Doesn't execute all intermediate phases that Maven would run

## Current Gap Analysis

### What's Missing in Nx
1. **Incomplete Lifecycle**: Nx doesn't run all Maven phases before install
2. **Goal Skipping**: Some bound goals in intermediate phases might be skipped
3. **Plugin Goal Discovery**: Not all plugin goals are discovered and orchestrated

### Current Target Structure
```json
{
  "install": {
    "executor": "nx:noop",
    "dependsOn": ["verify", "maven-install:install", "^install"]
  },
  "maven-install:install": {
    "executor": "nx:run-commands",
    "command": "mvn org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-install-plugin:install",
    "dependsOn": ["verify", "^install"]
  }
}
```

## Solution Requirements

To make `nx install` work exactly like `mvn install`, Nx needs to:

1. **Dynamic Phase Discovery**: Use `LifecycleExecutor.calculateExecutionPlan()` to get complete execution plan
2. **Goal Orchestration**: Create targets for all bound goals in execution order
3. **Phase Targets**: Maintain phase-level targets as orchestrators
4. **Dependency Chain**: Ensure proper dependency chain from validate  install

## Implementation Strategy

The `TargetGenerationService` already has the foundation with:
- `getApplicablePhases()` - discovers bound phases dynamically  
- `hasGoalsBoundToPhase()` - checks if phase has goals
- `LifecycleExecutor` integration - can calculate full execution plans

Need to enhance to:
1. Generate targets for ALL phases in lifecycle order
2. Create proper dependency chains between phases
3. Ensure all bound goals are orchestrated correctly

content.text:
## Key Differences

**`mvn install`** runs the complete Maven lifecycle: `validate`  `compile`  `test`  `package`  `verify`  `install` with all bound goals.

**`nx install`** currently only orchestrates to `verify`, then jumps to `maven-install:install` goal - missing intermediate phases.

## Making `nx install` Work Like `mvn install`

Your `TargetGenerationService` already has the foundation with `LifecycleExecutor` integration. To fix this:

1. **Enhanced Phase Discovery**: Use `calculateExecutionPlan("install")` to get complete execution order
2. **Full Lifecycle Orchestration**: Generate phase targets for ALL phases from validate  install  
3. **Proper Dependency Chain**: Each phase depends on the previous phase in Maven's lifecycle order

The current gap is that `install` only depends on `verify` when it should depend on a complete chain of all Maven phases that have bound goals.
